Similar to Monotype Script:  
 [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/monotype-script/](http://web.archive.org/web/20120219010638/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/monotype-script/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/monotype-script/")

No exact match, though.

This is like some of the work done by Nick Curtis, but I checked his site for scripts and also looked at his old Freebie fonts. There were no exact matches, but I think you're right that this is from the Deco era. Nick's closest styles were [Pismo Clambake](http://web.archive.org/web/20120219010638/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/nicksfonts/pismo-clambake-nf/) and [Jaunty Gent](http://web.archive.org/web/20120219010638/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/nicksfonts/jaunty-gent-nf/), which only show that the era is similar to his work here.

Is Nick around? Do you recognize this script from one of your books?

- Mike Yanega

Itâ€™s Troubadour Open or Troubadour Script. There is a version digitized by David Rakowski. Try [Rechtman](http://web.archive.org/web/20120219010638/http:/www.moorstation.org/typoasis/designers/rakowski/dr5/davy_f5.htm).

Nice work Akira. In Jaspert it says that 'Gracia' (Amsterdam) is one of the names it was sold under; also 'Donatello' (Niebolo) and 'Hertha' (Berling). The original design goes back to 1926 to Wagner & Schmidt, then cast by many foundries in 1927. Troubador Open was a Haas design by E. Thiele from 1931, if I read this right.

- Mike Yanega

[Rakowski](http://web.archive.org/web/20120219010638/http:/home.earthlink.net/~ziodavino/album1_009.htm) originally made his fonts as Mac shareware only. The original Rechtman, I believe, can be downloaded from the [Mac Font Vault](http://web.archive.org/web/20120219010638/http:/www.erik.co.uk/font/script.html).

Also, [Faces.com](http://web.archive.org/web/20120219010638/http:/www.faces.co.uk/fonts/fontview.cfm?productsku=IN100134) sells commercial versions of some of Rakowski's fonts. Presumably they are superior to the old shareware in technical quality or character set - but I don't know that for a fact.
